results.summary: A 16-year-old girl who was attacked on rush-hour bus in Birmingham died from a single stab wound to the chest, post-mortem tests reveal.
results.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/7d4f0825-981f-e348-ba5e-2f7b5eb2287b"><image id="66252167"/><paragraph role="introduction">A 16-year-old girl who was attacked on rush-hour bus in Birmingham died from a single stab wound to the chest, post-mortem tests have revealed.</paragraph><paragraph>Christina Edkins was stabbed upstairs on the bus on Hagley Road while on her way to school in Halesowen on Thursday.</paragraph><paragraph>Officers are continuing to question a 22-year-old man from the Walsall area who was arrested near the scene of the stabbing a few hours later.</paragraph><paragraph>West Midlands Police are investigating whether it was a random attack.</paragraph><paragraph>They said they were not looking for anyone else in connection with the killing.</paragraph><paragraph>Earlier, the force said about 16 people were on the bus at the time of the attack but they had only spoken to half of them.</paragraph><!-- Embedded video --><video media-id="66282375">    <caption>Pupils at Leasowes High School have mourned the death of Christina Edkins</caption>  </video><paragraph>They urged the other passengers to contact them urgently, even if they did not see the stabbing and had been sitting downstairs.</paragraph><paragraph>Officers said they believed Christina's attacker may have travelled on buses around the Birmingham area after the stabbing.</paragraph><crosshead>'Much loved'</crosshead><paragraph>Officers have released a CCTV image of a man wearing a jacket with a tiger design on the back and have urged anyone who saw him on Thursday between 0600 GMT and 1300 GMT to contact them.</paragraph><paragraph>West Midlands Police said extra officers were patrolling buses on Friday to reassure passengers.</paragraph><paragraph>Counsellors have been brought in to support pupils and staff at Leasowes High School, where Christina was a pupil.</paragraph><paragraph>Flowers, soft toys and balloons have been left outside the school.</paragraph><image id="66275743"/><paragraph>The school said it thanked "everyone for many offers of support" and extended heartfelt sympathy to Christina's family. </paragraph><paragraph>A book of remembrance has been opened at nearby St Peter's Church, in Lapal, Halesowen, where people can go to light a candle. </paragraph><paragraph>Christina's head teacher Neil Shaw described her as a "bright and popular student" who was "much loved by staff and students".</paragraph><crosshead>'Distressed and distraught'</crosshead><paragraph>The Reverend Mike Rutter, the vicar of St Peter's, said: "It's a terrible tragedy and many in our community will be affected.</paragraph><paragraph>"Our thoughts and prayers are with Christina's family and friends at this difficult time."</paragraph><paragraph>Det Supt Richard Baker said the teenager's family were distressed and distraught.</paragraph><pullOut title="At the scene" size="wide"><image id="66271928"/><byline name="Frankie McCamley" title="BBC WM reporter"><person><name>Frankie McCamley</name><function>BBC WM reporter</function></person></byline><paragraph>Outside Christina's school, queues of pupils have been turning up with flowers, balloons and teddy bears all morning. There are hundreds of flowers now outside the school gates.</paragraph><paragraph>There is none of the usual hustle and bustle you would expect during a school day. Instead, all the children are very visibly upset.</paragraph><paragraph>Flowers have also been left by the bus stop where the attack happened.</paragraph><paragraph>Christina's school friends want to do something in her memory. There has been talk of lots of things, including holding the school prom in her memory.</paragraph><paragraph>It is a very, very sombre atmosphere and very quiet. The community is taking this very hard.</paragraph></pullOut><paragraph>Halesowen and Rowley Regis MP James Morris said he would be meeting officials of National Express later to discuss bus safety.</paragraph><paragraph>He added: "The whole community is in shock here in Halesowen about this tragedy."</paragraph><paragraph>Police said they would be checking Christina's profiles on social media websites as part of the investigation, but there was nothing to suggest she was being targeted.</paragraph><paragraph>She is understood to have boarded the bus minutes before the attack, which happened at about 07:40 GMT.</paragraph><paragraph>The driver raised the alarm and attempts were made to revive the teenager, but she died at the scene.</paragraph><paragraph>Police have urged any further witnesses to contact them.</paragraph><paragraph>The 22-year-old was arrested near the Morrisons supermarket at Five Ways at about 12:30 GMT.</paragraph><paragraph>Ch Insp Kerry Blakeman, head of operations for Safer Travel, an organisation run by West Midlands Police, British Transport Police and Centro, said Birmingham's buses were safe to travel on.</paragraph><paragraph>He said: "If you feel uncomfortable with anything, contact the driver. </paragraph><paragraph>"There is a reporting mechanism between the buses and the police and officers can be contacted immediately."</paragraph></body>
